body:
when I list more usecases, find more complicated than i thought, results are different from expected ones, need to figure out what combination of conditions we should use, 
```
+++ b/src/arithmetic/bound_deducer.cc
@@ -128,6 +128,10 @@ class BoundDeducer: public IRVisitor {
     }

     // always use relax bound
+    Expr tmp_result = result / operand;
+    bool divided = can_prove(tmp_result * operand == result);
+    bool pos_result = can_prove(result >= 0);
+    std::cout << result <<": divided " << divided << " pos_result " << pos_result << std::endl;
     result = result / operand + (is_greater ? 1 : -1);
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23742050/34615824-1c5b2cf0-f271-11e7-9d2a-1428b1402115.png)

and here is my case:

```
def test_deduce_relax(a1,a2,b1,b2):
    a = tvm.var('a')
    b = tvm.var('b')
    b_s = tvm.arith.intset_interval(a1, a2)
    b_s2 = tvm.arith.intset_interval(b1, b2)
    e0 = b + a*4
    res1 = tvm.arith.DeduceBound(a, e0<17, {b: b_s}, {b: b_s})
    assert tvm.ir_pass.Simplify((res1.max() * 4 + b_s.max()) < 17).value == 1

    res1 = tvm.arith.DeduceBound(a, e0<17, {b: b_s2}, {b: b_s2})
    assert (tvm.ir_pass.Simplify((res1.max() * 4 + b_s2.max()) < 17)).value == 1

    res1 = tvm.arith.DeduceBound(a, e0>17, {b: b_s}, {b: b_s})
    assert (tvm.ir_pass.Simplify((res1.min() * 4 + b_s.min()) > 17)).value == 1

    res1 = tvm.arith.DeduceBound(a, e0>17, {b: b_s2}, {b: b_s2})
    assert (tvm.ir_pass.Simplify((res1.min() * 4 + b_s2.min()) > 17)).value == 1

    res1 = tvm.arith.DeduceBound(a, e0<=17, {b: b_s}, {b: b_s})
    assert (tvm.ir_pass.Simplify((res1.max() * 4 + b_s.max()) <= 17)).value == 1

    res1 = tvm.arith.DeduceBound(a, e0<=17, {b: b_s2}, {b: b_s2})
    assert (tvm.ir_pass.Simplify((res1.max() * 4 + b_s2.max()) <= 17)).value == 1

    res1 = tvm.arith.DeduceBound(a, e0>=17, {b: b_s}, {b: b_s})
    assert (tvm.ir_pass.Simplify((res1.min() * 4 + b_s.min()) >= 17)).value == 1

    res1 = tvm.arith.DeduceBound(a, e0>=17, {b: b_s2}, {b: b_s2})
    assert (tvm.ir_pass.Simplify((res1.min() * 4 + b_s2.min()) >= 17)).value == 1


  test_deduce_relax(0, 4, 10, 17)
    test_deduce_relax(1, 5, 17, 25)
    test_deduce_relax(1, 5, 10, 17)
    test_deduce_relax(8, 16, 29, 45)
```
enable CUDA and LLVM on your cmake, see https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L19
add @ZihengJiang to the reviewer

Fair enough regarding the workaround. Thanks.
However, is a stage in a "well-defined" state if it has multiple copies of the same IV and different parts of the data structure of the stage point to different copies? In other words, do later processing of schedule (i.e., after `normalize()`) make any assumption that is not satisfied by the state mentioned above? If the answer is yes, we need to fix `normalize()` or the assumptions made by later processing. If the answer is no, we can leave things as is and suffice to avoiding calling `normalize()`.

The normalize is a sugar to do automatic schedule transformation, and such transformation that calls rebase is well defined. The lowering procedure only looks at the result schedule relation tree, which is always well defined
cc @were

for the case when we need 2D texture, we might be able to use the following workaround.

Always allocate memory as i = 2^k * y + x, where x and y are two dimensional axis. k is the folding ideal packing length over the x dimension, say 10

so we can easily use bit operation to get y and x from global index i, and reconstruct vice versa
@ZihengJiang  can you contribute an example with more level of tiling and get to actual numpy perf?

This is an example running on MacOS. However, I believe @ZihengJiang 's scheduling should apply in most cases. On MacOS, by default `numpy.dot` links to [Accelerate](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/accelerate). I would assume it achieves similar performance as OpenBlas and MKL. Lastly, adding multi-threading is necessary, and consequently, we should use `time.time()` instead of `time.clock()` to measure the time for `numpy.dot`. A better (more apple-to-apple) comparison is to use `timeit`, since the tvm-built function averages elapsed times across multiple runs.

In normalize(), binded iter_var would not be rebased (see [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/schedule/schedule_dataflow_rewrite.cc#L248)). However, In this case, the iter axis was split before being binded, so InferBound() would return an error. 
If we call normalize() before binding the axis, we would face the problem as issue #733

Tvm has backends in which target related intrinsics are emited in llvm IR and fed to llvm right away. because abstraction of tvm is higher than traditional compiler like gcc/llvm, so it would be easier for tvm to generate instructions like vector or matrix, that is to say, tvm can offload some difficult work from  traditional compiler and no need to do low level optimizations itself but just use them directly.
@yuruofeifei can you check whether enabling avx2 makes a difference?
this should work fine when combined with automatic constant unrolling to unroll this loop
automatic constant unrolling is done via another pass

since the range of the bound is dynamic depending on, there is a bit of ambiguity in this bind, as we are binding a dynamic ranged iter var([x, x+extent)) to a thread. We can do an explicit rebase on xx before bind, which might help solve the issue.

interval combination is a more rare case that we do not yet need to support, modify the test-case for now and restrict it to contain one interval without multiply
specifically, set c to be a constant number in the above testcase

one way to solve loop partition issue is inserting a storage_rewrite before loop partition, but nothing changes for case above

```
diff --git a/python/tvm/build_module.py b/python/tvm/build_module.py
index 0ca4b3c..288c106 100644
--- a/python/tvm/build_module.py
+++ b/python/tvm/build_module.py
@@ -223,6 +223,7 @@ def lower(sch,
         stmt = f(stmt)
     # Phase 2
     if not simple_mode:
+        stmt = ir_pass.StorageRewrite(stmt)
         stmt = ir_pass.LoopPartition(stmt, cfg.partition_const_loop)
     stmt = ir_pass.VectorizeLoop(stmt)
     stmt = ir_pass.InjectVirtualThread(stmt)
```

And my code just include:

n = 1024
l = 128
m = 235
bias = tvm.var('bias', dtype=tvm.float32)
A = tvm.placeholder((n, l), name='A')
B = tvm.placeholder((l, m), name='B')
C = tvm.extern((n, m), [A, B],
               lambda ins, outs: tvm.call_packed(
                   "tvm.contrib.cblas.matmul",
                   ins[0], ins[1], outs[0], False, False), name="C")
D = tvm.compute(C.shape, lambda i, j: C[i,j] + bias, name="D")
s = tvm.create_schedule(D.op)

ctx = tvm.cpu(0)
f = tvm.build(s, [A, B, D, bias], "llvm")
a = tvm.nd.array(np.random.uniform(size=(n, l)).astype(A.dtype), ctx)
b = tvm.nd.array(np.random.uniform(size=(l, m)).astype(B.dtype), ctx)
d = tvm.nd.array(np.zeros((n, m), dtype=D.dtype), ctx)
bb = 10.0
f(a, b, d, bb)
np.testing.assert_allclose(
    d.asnumpy(), np.dot(a.asnumpy(), b.asnumpy()) + 10, rtol=1e-5)

Thanks, 

For my test case in the generated llvm code, I see 2 functions: default_function and default_function_compute. Default function has a lot of checks and assertions on the inputs and
I just want to time the default_function_compute running time. Is there a way to do this?
Right now, I'm having to write a wrapper around the default_function_compute function interfacing to the assembly code  and am timing it. I get drastically different times, the compute time is much less than the time that does all the assertions and checks.
I'm trying to do the above timing for benchmarking the performance in terms of FLOPS.

We should be able to modify function generator to remove those checks and assertions by modifying MakeAPI. However, the relative time cost of the input consistency checking should be negligible compared to the time cost of actually running the code, both in terms of complexity and cost of running it for the normal workload we care, so we should not worry that much on the overhead of this function launch.
you will need to build tvm with cblas support enabled by change config.mk. The default installation do not install cblas contrib

Was caused by non-merge rule for local memory used in normal compiler(as they lower to register values)

If possible, could the function that does the computation (default_function_compute_) be exported from the module , so that it would be  possible to invoke it using time_evaluator and passing in some arguments ? A debug mode could be added for this..

One thing we need to be careful about is the timing methodology. When you do the timing, the time you get from first calling the function and second time you call the function can differ. Since data need to be loaded into cache, as well as the instructions(or something like PTX that need to be JITed).

So we always need to skip first invocation when measuring the time

I removed schedule_upsampling for now, but if we need bilinear upsampling later, we will need a schedule for upsampling.

I am observing a factor of ~6x slowdown on a single core of Skylake when running the convolution via tvm as opposed to running just the computation code generated from tvm via  a c driver. I am attaching a simple source archive below, which if you could try on your end to verify, I'd greatly appreciate.
It has a README and a Makefile below:
[performance.tar.gz](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/files/1624213/performance.tar.gz)


Thanks,
Anand

There are two possibilities in here

- The difference was due to as you mentioned, the cost in the checks(this is your conjecture)
- The difference was due to the fact that the way things are created and linked.
    - The default function uses LLVM's JITModule
    - Your benchmark uses direct C module

We did observe sometimes LLVM's JITModule being slower than directly export the module to a .so file and then load it back later.

To verify which one is the case, please do two things:

- Do a f.export_library("xx.so") preferably with icc, and load it back later using tvm.module.load then run the time evaluator benchmark
- Do a normal call into the wrapped function. The calling convention follows, with the same parameter definition in here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/include/tvm/runtime/c_runtime_api.h#L256 

```c++
extern "C" wrapped_func(TVMValue* arg_values, int* type_codes, int num_args);
```

Oh, thanks a lot, for this information, I'll try it out..

Regards,
Anand

Yes the export  to a library and then running gave me the same performance as calling from the c driver,
this is great, thanks!
